column4: apt is configured to use the CD by default, you can disable it in synaptic's repositories config, or comment out the first line in /etc/apt/sources.list
put a # in front of the whole line
you'll need to tell synaptic to reload the package lists, or run "sudo apt-get update", then it won't ask for the CD again
do you know which partition it is you want to mount?
ok, have you made a mount point for it?
I'm just trying to find out where abouts it is that its failing, if you ahve any error messages that would be helpful ;)
fd0 is floppy
hd means hard disk (IDE usually)
if you run "sudo fdisk -l" in a terminal it will list all partitions on all hard disks in your system
so 'D" should be hda2 right?
maybe, run the fdisk command I pasted above, it will show you the FAT partition and the start of the line will tell you which /dev/ entry to use
i have 1 NTFS 3 FAT 1 Swap and 1 ext3 partition
ok, D should be the lowest numbered of the FAT partitions I would think

sudo mkdir /mnt/fatdrive will make a mount point for it, then try "mount -t vfat /dev/hdNX /mnt/fatdrive" (replace hdNX with hda2 or whatever it was the fdisk output said), if it doesn't work, tell me the error and run "tail /var/log/syslog" and see if there are any errors in there
if it works then you can turn it into a line in /etc/fstab and it will be mounted every time you boot
those look ok, assuming hda5 and 6 are the correct partitions
hda5 is mounting but not hda6..
sudo tail /var/log/syslog - any obvious errors in there?
ok :)
np :)
why i am not getting soung in XMMS>
I'm not sure about sound stuff, I have a card that does a lot of stuff for ubuntu, but I think you might want to install/use the esound output plugin for xmms
others may know better though
at least try the oss, alsa and esound/esd output plugins :)
